edge: The accompanying soundtrack, Glitter, became Carey's lowest showing on the charts. The first single, 'Loverboy', peaked at number two on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart, but only after Virgin Records spurred sales of the single by dropping the price down to 99 cents.

Carey was unable to film a music video for the single, 'Never Too Far', as she was still recovering from her breakdown. Instead, a video was created using a scene taken directly from the film, where Billie Frank (played by Carey) sings the song at Madison Square Garden during her first sold-out concert.
Frank's performance of the song in the film omits its entire second verse, and the song's development runs in parallel with the film's love story.

The album's third single, 'Don't Stop (Funkin' 4 Jamaica)', released on December 10, 2001, mirrored the same weak charting as 'Never Too Far', although receiving more rotation on MTV due to its video.

In 2001, Virgin Records dropped Mariah Carey from their label due to the poor sales of Glitter's soundtrack album. However, in 2018, the social media campaign #JusticeForGlitter helped the soundtrack soar to number-one on iTunes charts in multiple countries and re-entered Billboard's Soundtracks chart at number 14. Carey later added songs from the album in a medley as part of her Caution World Tour in 2019.

The final single released from Glitter's soundtrack album was 'Reflections (Care Enough)', which featured Mariah Carey singing into a microphone on the screen at one time. The song received a limited release in Japan on December 15, 2001, and following its limited promotional push from Virgin, it failed to make much of an impact.

Since its 2001 release, Glitter's soundtrack album has been certified platinum. However, due to the poor sales of the album, Virgin Records dropped Carey from the label and bought her out of their $100 million contract with her for $20 million.
